questions.question: A company forecasted demand of 1,000 units, but actual customer orders were 1,200. What is this difference called?
questions.explanation: Forecast error is the difference between actual demand and forecasted demand. Managing forecast error is critical for planning safety stock and improving forecast accuracy.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 2 – Demand Management (Forecasting and Forecast Error, pp. 2.35–2.40)

questions.question: Which inventory is held to protect against uncertainty in demand or supply?
questions.explanation: Safety stock acts as a buffer against variations in demand or supply lead time. It reduces the risk of stockouts.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Types of Inventory – Safety Stock, pp. 4.15–4.20)

questions.question: The primary output of the Master Production Schedule (MPS) is:
questions.explanation: MPS translates the production plan into specific build schedules for end items, balancing demand with available resources.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 3 – Master Planning (Purpose and Outputs of MPS, pp. 3.25–3.30)

questions.question: Which technique is used to validate the feasibility of the Master Production Schedule (MPS)?
questions.explanation: RCCP checks whether critical resources (like bottleneck work centers, labor, and key machines) have enough capacity to support the MPS.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Capacity Planning (Rough-Cut Capacity Planning, pp. 4.10–4.15)

questions.question: The main purpose of Sales and Operations Planning (S&OP) is to:

options.a: Forecast sales at the product level
options.b: Reconcile supply and demand at an aggregate level

questions.explanation: S&OP aligns business strategy, sales forecasts, and operations planning to ensure a feasible, balanced plan that supports financial and operational goals.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – S&OP (Purpose and Benefits, pp. 2.5–2.12)

questions.question: Which type of bill of material (BOM) is used to plan options and variations in a product family?
questions.explanation: A planning BOM is used in forecasting and MPS to plan for product families with many variations.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Bills of Material, pp. 3.20–3.25)

questions.question: Which system uses actual consumption data to trigger replenishment signals?
questions.explanation: Kanban is a pull system where replenishment is triggered by actual consumption rather than forecast.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Lean and JIT, pp. 3.45–3.50)

questions.question: Which measure reflects the percentage of time a machine is actually producing compared to available time?
questions.explanation: Utilization is the ratio of actual running time to total available time.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Capacity Planning (Capacity Measurement, pp. 4.25–4.30)

questions.question: In MRP, which file contains information about lead times, lot sizes, and safety stock for each item?
questions.explanation: The item master file includes planning data such as lot sizes, lead times, and safety stock requirements.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (MRP Inputs, pp. 3.35–3.40)

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of time fences in MPS?

options.a: To freeze near-term schedules and provide stability

questions.explanation: Time fences prevent unnecessary changes to production schedules close to execution, improving stability.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 3 – Master Planning (Time Fences, pp. 3.40–3.45)

questions.question: Which distribution planning technique determines the timing and quantity of stock movements between facilities?
questions.explanation: DRP is the time-phased planning tool for distribution networks, determining when and how much inventory to replenish.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 5 – Distribution (DRP, pp. 5.10–5.15)

questions.question: Which inventory management approach focuses on continuous counting rather than annual physical inventory?
questions.explanation: Cycle counting is a perpetual method to maintain inventory accuracy by checking selected items regularly.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Cycle Counting, pp. 4.35–4.40)

questions.question: Which lot-sizing technique always orders the exact net requirements for each period?
questions.explanation: Lot-for-lot ordering matches order quantity to net requirements for each period, minimizing inventory but increasing order frequency.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Lot Sizing Techniques, pp. 3.50–3.55)

questions.question: Which measure indicates how much demand can be met from current inventory without replenishment?
questions.explanation: ATP indicates the uncommitted portion of inventory and planned production available to support new customer orders.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 3 – Master Planning (Available-to-Promise, pp. 3.18–3.22)

questions.question: Which document authorizes the release of materials to production?
questions.explanation: A work order authorizes production to start and allows materials to be issued from inventory to the shop floor.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Work Orders, pp. 3.65–3.70)

questions.question: Which planning approach starts at the finished goods level and works backward to determine requirements?
questions.explanation: MRP is a backward-scheduling process that calculates requirements for components based on the MPS.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (MRP Logic, pp. 3.30–3.35)

questions.question: Which metric measures how many times inventory is sold and replaced during a given period?
questions.explanation: Inventory turnover is calculated as cost of goods sold divided by average inventory, showing how efficiently inventory is used.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Inventory Performance Metrics, pp. 4.45–4.50)

questions.question: What is the main purpose of a routing file?

options.b: To sequence operations and identify resources

questions.explanation: The routing file defines the operations sequence, work centers, and times needed to produce a product.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Routing Data, pp. 3.60–3.65)

questions.question: Which system integrates financial, distribution, and manufacturing data into a single database?
questions.explanation: ERP integrates enterprise-wide processes across finance, manufacturing, and supply chain in a centralized system.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 1 – Basics of Supply Chain Management (ERP, pp. 1.40–1.45)

questions.question: Which inventory type results from production faster than customer demand?
questions.explanation: Anticipation inventory is built in advance of predictable demand increases or seasonal fluctuations.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Anticipation Inventory, pp. 4.12–4.15)

questions.question: What is the main purpose of capacity requirements planning (CRP)?

options.c: To plan detailed work center loads

questions.explanation: CRP calculates the load at each work center to ensure capacity matches planned orders.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Capacity Planning (Capacity Requirements Planning, pp. 4.20–4.25)

questions.question: Which approach uses ABC classification to determine inventory management effort?
questions.explanation: Cycle counting often uses ABC analysis so high-value (A) items are counted more frequently than low-value items.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Cycle Counting Approaches, pp. 4.35–4.40)

questions.question: Which measure evaluates the ability to deliver customer orders on the promised date?
questions.explanation: On-time delivery measures the percentage of orders delivered as promised, reflecting reliability in scheduling.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 1 – Basics of Supply Chain Management (Customer Service Metrics, pp. 1.25–1.30)

questions.question: What is the main output of material requirements planning (MRP)?
questions.explanation: MRP produces time-phased planned orders for procurement and production to meet dependent demand.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (MRP Outputs, pp. 3.40–3.45)

questions.question: Which process translates the business plan into a mid-term operational plan?
questions.explanation: S&OP is the cross-functional process for reconciling supply and demand at an aggregate level over the medium term.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – S&OP (Linking Business Plan and Operations, pp. 2.8–2.12)

questions.question: Which concept refers to the longest path through a project schedule?
questions.explanation: Critical path is the sequence of dependent activities with zero slack that determines total project duration.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 5 – Distribution and Logistics (Project Scheduling Concepts, pp. 5.25–5.30)

questions.question: Which lean concept focuses on producing only what is needed when it is needed?
questions.explanation: Pull systems authorize production based on actual consumption, minimizing excess WIP and inventory.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Lean Principles, pp. 3.42–3.48)

questions.question: Which inventory performance measure is defined as the percentage of demand met without backorders?
questions.explanation: Fill rate measures the proportion of demand filled directly from stock, showing customer service effectiveness.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Customer Service Metrics, pp. 4.42–4.45)

questions.question: Which type of capacity is based on the maximum output a system can produce under ideal conditions?
questions.explanation: Theoretical capacity is based on maximum output with no downtime or inefficiencies; it is rarely attainable.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Capacity Planning (Types of Capacity, pp. 4.8–4.12)

questions.question: Which measure indicates how quickly inventory is sold and replenished during a specific period?
questions.explanation: The inventory turnover ratio measures how often inventory is sold and replaced over a given period, reflecting efficiency of stock management.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Performance Metrics, pp. 4.46–4.50)

questions.question: Which document specifies the materials, quantities, and sequence needed to produce an item?
questions.explanation: A Bill of Material (BOM) lists components, subassemblies, and their quantities required to make a finished product.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Bills of Material, pp. 3.20–3.25)

questions.question: Which system balances supply and demand by using time-phased order releases?
questions.explanation: MRP plans time-phased order releases to meet dependent demand while considering lead times and inventory policies.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (MRP Logic, pp. 3.30–3.35)

questions.question: Which term describes the alignment of long-term business strategy with operations planning?
questions.explanation: S&OP ensures alignment between long-term strategy, financial goals, and mid-range operations planning.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – S&OP (Strategic Alignment, pp. 2.10–2.15)

questions.question: Which scheduling method aims to synchronize production with the rate of customer demand?
questions.explanation: Takt time scheduling matches production pace to the rate of customer demand, minimizing overproduction.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Lean Concepts, pp. 3.48–3.52)

questions.question: Which concept represents a planned order that has not yet been released?
questions.explanation: Planned order releases are future orders suggested by MRP but not yet released to production or suppliers.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (MRP Outputs, pp. 3.40–3.45)

questions.question: Which type of stock is in transit between locations in a supply chain?
questions.explanation: Pipeline inventory represents goods in transit between facilities or supply chain nodes.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Types of Inventory, pp. 4.18–4.22)

questions.question: Which planning level focuses on long-term decisions such as facility location and capacity investment?
questions.explanation: Strategic planning involves long-term capacity, facility, and investment decisions aligning with business goals.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 1 – Basics of Supply Chain Management (Planning Hierarchy, pp. 1.15–1.20)

questions.question: Which lot-sizing method balances setup cost and carrying cost by ordering at an economic quantity?
questions.explanation: EOQ minimizes total cost by balancing setup and holding costs.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Lot Sizing, pp. 3.50–3.55)

questions.question: Which approach ensures production orders are only released when capacity is available?
questions.explanation: Finite loading schedules orders only when sufficient capacity is available, improving feasibility of plans.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Capacity Planning (Finite and Infinite Loading, pp. 4.15–4.20)

questions.question: Which scheduling method focuses on completing jobs by their due dates while minimizing lateness?
questions.explanation: The earliest due date rule prioritizes jobs with the earliest deadlines to minimize lateness.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Scheduling Rules, pp. 3.55–3.60)

questions.question: Which manufacturing environment produces standardized products in large volumes with low flexibility?
questions.explanation: MTS environments produce standardized products in anticipation of demand, with low customization.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 1 – Basics of Supply Chain Management (Manufacturing Environments, pp. 1.20–1.25)

questions.question: Which Lean concept involves leveling production to reduce variability?
questions.explanation: Heijunka levels production to smooth demand variability and optimize flow.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Lean Tools, pp. 3.45–3.50)

questions.question: Which capacity measure reflects actual demonstrated output over time?
questions.explanation: Demonstrated capacity is based on actual historical output, reflecting realistic performance.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Capacity Planning (Capacity Measures, pp. 4.12–4.16)

questions.question: Which order policy triggers replenishment only when inventory falls below a set level?
questions.explanation: The reorder point system initiates replenishment when inventory reaches a predetermined level.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Reorder Point Planning, pp. 3.55–3.60)

questions.question: Which process focuses on short-term scheduling and execution on the shop floor?
questions.explanation: Detailed scheduling and planning focuses on shop-floor scheduling, order release, and execution.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Short-term Scheduling, pp. 3.10–3.15)

questions.question: Which customer service measure calculates the portion of demand satisfied directly from stock?
questions.explanation: Fill rate is the percentage of demand that can be met immediately from available inventory.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Customer Service Metrics, pp. 4.40–4.45)

questions.question: Which tool is used to analyze demand variability by categorizing items based on value and frequency of use?
questions.explanation: ABC classification segments inventory into A, B, and C categories based on value and frequency, guiding control efforts.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (ABC Analysis, pp. 4.28–4.33)

questions.question: Which output of capacity requirements planning (CRP) shows the load versus available capacity at each work center?
questions.explanation: CRP generates load profiles that compare planned workload against available capacity at each work center.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Capacity Planning (CRP Outputs, pp. 4.22–4.28)

questions.question: Which lean practice empowers workers to stop production when a defect occurs?
questions.explanation: Jidoka enables workers to stop production when a problem arises, ensuring quality at the source.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Lean Principles, pp. 3.42–3.48)

questions.question: What is meant by "dependent demand" in inventory management?

options.a: Demand for finished goods based on customer orders
options.b: Demand for components or raw materials based on the production schedule

questions.explanation: Dependent demand is demand directly related to the demand for another item, usually components needed to make finished products.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Demand Types, pp. 3.10–3.15)

questions.question: Which inventory method values ending inventory based on the most recent purchase cost?
questions.explanation: LIFO assumes the last purchased items are used first, so ending inventory reflects older costs.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Inventory Valuation Methods, pp. 4.60–4.65)

questions.question: Which type of demand is directly influenced by customer orders rather than forecasts?
questions.explanation: Independent demand is based on actual customer orders and forecasts for finished goods, unlike dependent demand which comes from production schedules.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 2 – Demand Management (Demand Types, pp. 2.10–2.15)

questions.question: Which production strategy builds inventory in advance of seasonal demand peaks?
questions.explanation: The level production strategy keeps production steady and uses inventory to absorb demand fluctuations, particularly during seasonal peaks.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – S&OP (Production Strategies, pp. 2.20–2.25)

questions.question: Which inventory management principle states that a small percentage of items often accounts for a large percentage of value?
questions.explanation: The Pareto principle (80/20 rule) is used in ABC analysis, where a small number of high-value items typically represent most of the total inventory value.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (ABC Classification, pp. 4.28–4.33)

questions.question: Which lean concept focuses on reducing setup times to allow smaller lot sizes?
questions.explanation: SMED reduces setup times, enabling smaller lot sizes, more flexibility, and reduced inventory in lean manufacturing.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Lean Tools, pp. 3.45–3.50)

questions.question: Which input is required for capacity planning but not for MRP?
questions.explanation: Capacity planning requires work center availability data to assess whether planned orders can be executed with available resources.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Capacity Planning (Inputs to Capacity Planning, pp. 4.15–4.20)

questions.question: Which concept in project management provides a buffer to protect project completion dates?
questions.explanation: The critical chain buffer protects the project completion date against variations in task durations and resource availability.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 5 – Distribution and Logistics (Critical Chain Concepts, pp. 5.28–5.32)

questions.question: Which type of cost increases as inventory levels rise?
questions.explanation: Carrying costs, such as storage, insurance, and obsolescence, increase with higher inventory levels.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Inventory Costs, pp. 4.5–4.10)

questions.question: Which scheduling method uses visual tools to display operations against time?
questions.explanation: Gantt charts graphically display operations or tasks over time, commonly used for scheduling and progress tracking.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (Scheduling Tools, pp. 3.55–3.60)

questions.question: Which replenishment approach ensures suppliers deliver materials exactly when needed for production?
questions.explanation: JIT aims to receive materials exactly when needed, minimizing inventory and waste while improving flow.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling and Planning (JIT, pp. 3.40–3.45)

questions.question: Which planning tool links long-term strategy with day-to-day operations?
questions.explanation: S&OP serves as the bridge between strategic plans and operational execution, aligning supply, demand, and financial objectives.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – S&OP (Strategic Alignment, pp. 2.10–2.15)

questions.question: Which document communicates the quantities and timing of end items to be produced?
questions.explanation: The Master Production Schedule (MPS) defines what end items will be produced, in what quantities, and when they will be delivered.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – Master Planning (MPS, pp. 2.25–2.30)

questions.question: Which type of inventory is held to protect against uncertainty in demand or supply?
questions.explanation: Safety stock is held as a buffer against variability in demand or lead time to prevent stockouts.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Types of Inventory, pp. 4.15–4.20)

questions.question: Which system focuses on managing the flow of materials from suppliers through to customers?
questions.explanation: Supply Chain Management (SCM) integrates suppliers, manufacturers, warehouses, and customers to ensure smooth flow of materials and information.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 1 – Supply Chain Overview (SCM, pp. 1.5–1.10)

questions.question: Which metric is used to measure how effectively inventory is being utilized?
questions.explanation: Inventory turnover measures how many times inventory is sold and replaced over a period, indicating efficiency in inventory use.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Performance Measures, pp. 4.40–4.45)

questions.question: Which forecasting technique relies on historical data without considering external factors?
questions.explanation: Time series forecasting uses historical demand patterns such as trend and seasonality to predict future demand.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 2 – Demand (Forecasting Methods, pp. 2.25–2.30)

questions.question: Which strategy delays final product assembly until customer orders are received?
questions.explanation: Assemble-to-order keeps components ready and final assembly is done only after customer orders are received, balancing responsiveness and efficiency.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 3 – Transformation of Demand (Production Environments, pp. 3.15–3.20)

questions.question: Which scheduling rule gives priority to jobs with the least amount of time remaining until due date?
questions.explanation: The earliest due date rule prioritizes jobs with the soonest due dates, reducing lateness and missed deadlines.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling (Dispatching Rules, pp. 3.30–3.35)

questions.question: Which type of bill of material shows all components needed across multiple products?
questions.explanation: A super BOM includes all possible components and options for multiple product configurations, useful in assemble-to-order environments.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 1 – MRP (Types of BOM, pp. 1.15–1.20)

questions.question: Which lot-sizing technique always orders just enough to cover requirements for a specific period?
questions.explanation: Lot-for-lot ordering exactly matches order quantities to net requirements for each period, minimizing inventory but increasing order frequency.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 1 – MRP (Lot Sizing Methods, pp. 1.30–1.35)

questions.question: Which measure indicates the ability of a system to deliver customer orders when promised?
questions.explanation: On-time delivery is a key performance measure of customer service, showing the percentage of orders delivered as promised.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 1 – Supply Chain Overview (Customer Service Metrics, pp. 1.25–1.30)

questions.question: Which capacity planning tool evaluates critical resources like labor and machines against the Master Production Schedule?
questions.explanation: Rough-Cut Capacity Planning ensures that key resources can support the MPS before committing to production.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – Master Planning (Capacity Planning, pp. 2.40–2.45)

questions.question: Which production layout groups similar processes together, such as all drilling machines in one area?
questions.explanation: A process layout arranges resources by function, improving flexibility for varied product types.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 3 – Transformation of Demand (Manufacturing Layouts, pp. 3.30–3.35)

questions.question: Which type of inventory is created when production exceeds immediate customer demand?
questions.explanation: Cycle stock results from production or purchasing in lot sizes larger than immediate demand requirements.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Inventory Categories, pp. 4.15–4.20)

questions.question: Which continuous improvement method focuses on reducing variation and defects to near zero?
questions.explanation: Six Sigma emphasizes statistical tools to reduce process variation and achieve high quality.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Continuous Improvement (Six Sigma, pp. 4.20–4.25)

questions.question: Which scheduling approach uses finite capacity and adjusts for resource constraints in real time?
questions.explanation: Finite loading respects actual resource limits, ensuring schedules are feasible with available capacity.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling (Loading Methods, pp. 3.15–3.20)

questions.question: Which type of demand comes directly from customer orders?
questions.explanation: Independent demand is not tied to any other product and comes directly from customer requirements.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 2 – Demand (Demand Types, pp. 2.10–2.15)

questions.question: Which inventory accuracy measure compares recorded balances with physical counts?
questions.explanation: Cycle counting is a method of auditing inventory continuously by comparing physical counts with system records.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Inventory Accuracy, pp. 4.50–4.55)

questions.question: Which supply chain strategy involves sharing demand forecasts and inventory data with suppliers?
questions.explanation: VMI shifts responsibility for replenishment to suppliers, using shared demand and inventory information.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – Master Planning (Supply Chain Collaboration, pp. 2.50–2.55)

questions.question: Which type of order policy maintains a fixed interval between replenishments?
questions.explanation: The periodic review system places orders at regular intervals, adjusting quantity based on actual demand.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Replenishment Policies, pp. 4.25–4.30)

questions.question: Which performance measure calculates the percentage of time a machine is actually producing versus available time?
questions.explanation: Machine utilization measures the actual productive time relative to the machine's available time.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling (Performance Metrics, pp. 3.40–3.45)

questions.question: Which strategy delays final product differentiation until customer demand is known?
questions.explanation: Postponement delays product customization until customer orders arrive, reducing inventory risk.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – Master Planning (Postponement Strategy, pp. 2.55–2.60)

questions.question: Which term refers to the longest sequence of dependent activities in a project schedule?
questions.explanation: The critical path is the longest set of dependent tasks that determines the shortest project completion time.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling (Project Scheduling, pp. 3.25–3.30)

questions.question: Which measure evaluates how frequently inventory is sold and replaced over a period?
questions.explanation: Inventory turnover measures efficiency by dividing cost of goods sold by average inventory.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Performance Metrics, pp. 4.60–4.65)

questions.question: Which capacity strategy adds resources only when demand exceeds current capability?
questions.explanation: Lag strategy waits until demand is proven before adding capacity, minimizing risk of overcapacity.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – Master Planning (Capacity Strategies, pp. 2.35–2.40)

questions.question: Which system uses visual signals like cards to authorize material movement or production?
questions.explanation: Kanban is a visual pull system that signals when to move or produce items.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Continuous Improvement (Lean and Kanban, pp. 4.15–4.20)

questions.question: Which cost includes expenses like storage, insurance, obsolescence, and capital tied up in inventory?
questions.explanation: Carrying costs represent the expenses of holding inventory, including space, handling, and risk.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Inventory Costs, pp. 4.20–4.25)

questions.question: Which sourcing strategy uses a single supplier to gain economies of scale?
questions.explanation: Single sourcing allows stronger supplier relationships and lower costs but increases supply risk.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 1 – Strategy (Sourcing Approaches, pp. 1.40–1.45)

questions.question: Which lot-sizing rule orders the exact net requirements for each period?
questions.explanation: Lot-for-lot minimizes inventory by ordering only what is needed each period.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Lot Sizing, pp. 4.30–4.35)

questions.question: Which type of production system produces high-volume, standardized products with low flexibility?
questions.explanation: Continuous production runs 24/7 with minimal variation, such as in chemicals or oil refining.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 3 – Transformation of Demand (Production Systems, pp. 3.20–3.25)

questions.question: Which performance metric measures how often customer orders are delivered on time and in full?
questions.explanation: Perfect order fulfillment tracks orders delivered on time, complete, damage-free, and with correct documentation.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 1 – Strategy (Performance Metrics, pp. 1.60–1.65)

questions.question: Which approach to quality emphasizes designing processes to prevent defects rather than inspecting finished goods?
questions.explanation: Quality at the source requires employees to take responsibility for producing defect-free work, preventing errors early.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Continuous Improvement (Quality Approaches, pp. 4.30–4.35)

questions.question: Which method balances material flow through constraints by scheduling work at the pace of the slowest resource?
questions.explanation: Drum-buffer-rope schedules the system to the constraint’s pace, protecting flow with time buffers.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling (Theory of Constraints, pp. 3.45–3.50)

questions.question: Which forecast error measure expresses error as a percentage of actual demand?
questions.explanation: MAPE (Mean Absolute Percentage Error) allows error comparison across different scales by using percentages.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 2 – Demand (Forecast Performance, pp. 2.35–2.40)

questions.question: Which production environment starts work only after receiving a customer order?
questions.explanation: Make-to-order reduces finished goods inventory by producing only after an order is confirmed.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 3 – Transformation of Demand (Manufacturing Environments, pp. 3.15–3.20)

questions.question: Which term refers to the difference between available supply and forecasted demand in a master production schedule?
questions.explanation: Available-to-promise (ATP) represents the uncommitted portion of inventory or planned production available for customer orders.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – Master Planning (ATP, pp. 2.45–2.50)

questions.question: Which replenishment system issues orders at fixed time intervals regardless of demand?
questions.explanation: Periodic review replenishes inventory at set intervals, adjusting order quantities to restore target levels.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Replenishment Methods, pp. 4.40–4.45)

questions.question: Which process continuously compares actual performance with planned performance to ensure alignment?
questions.explanation: Closed-loop control provides feedback to adjust operations so they stay aligned with plans.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 1 – Supply Chain Overview (Control Systems, pp. 1.35–1.40)

questions.question: Which lot-sizing technique groups requirements into weekly buckets to reduce order frequency?
questions.explanation: Period order quantity accumulates requirements for a set number of periods, balancing ordering and holding costs.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Lot Sizing Methods, pp. 4.30–4.35)

questions.question: Which scheduling method prioritizes jobs based on the shortest processing time?
questions.explanation: Shortest processing time reduces average job flow time and increases throughput efficiency.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling (Dispatching Rules, pp. 3.55–3.60)

questions.question: Which planning horizon defines the short-term period where changes to the master schedule are highly restricted?
questions.explanation: The frozen zone limits changes in the near term to protect material and capacity commitments.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – Master Planning (Time Fences, pp. 2.50–2.55)

questions.question: Which manufacturing strategy focuses on eliminating variability and defects through data-driven analysis?

questions.question: Which scheduling technique displays project activities as bars against a time scale?

questions.question: Which method of lot sizing seeks to minimize the total cost by balancing carrying and setup costs?

questions.question: Which type of inventory is intentionally built up to cover seasonal peaks in demand?

questions.question: Which supplier relationship emphasizes collaboration, joint problem solving, and long-term value creation?

questions.question: Which demand pattern is characterized by repeated rises and falls at regular intervals, such as holidays or seasons?

questions.question: In material requirements planning, which type of demand is driven directly by customer orders?

questions.question: Which planning horizon is typically the shortest, focusing on daily and weekly execution?
questions.explanation: Operational planning manages short-term execution such as shop floor schedules.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 3 – Transformation of Demand (Planning Horizons, pp. 3.10–3.15)

questions.question: Which lean tool focuses on reducing equipment changeover time to increase flexibility?
questions.explanation: SMED (Single-Minute Exchange of Dies) minimizes setup time to improve responsiveness.

questions.question: Which technique in project management identifies the sequence of dependent tasks that determines total project duration?

questions.question: Which type of production process is most suitable for customized, low-volume, high-variety products?

questions.question: Which inventory management approach involves automatically reordering when stock reaches a set minimum level?

questions.question: Which forecasting method uses past averages to smooth out random variations in demand?
questions.explanation: Moving average forecasts smooth random fluctuations by averaging recent demand values.

questions.question: Which sourcing approach uses multiple suppliers to reduce supply risk?

questions.question: Which type of buffer in Theory of Constraints protects the bottleneck from supply disruptions?

questions.question: Which lean principle refers to producing only what is needed, when it is needed?

questions.question: Which scheduling technique balances work content across workstations to reduce idle time?

questions.question: Which forecasting approach combines opinions from a panel of experts to reach consensus?

questions.question: Which supply chain strategy focuses on maintaining minimal finished goods and customizing late in the process?

questions.question: Which metric measures how efficiently materials are converted into finished goods?

questions.question: Which inventory replenishment approach uses visual signals such as cards or bins?
questions.explanation: Kanban is a pull-based replenishment system using visual cues to trigger orders.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Continuous Improvement (Lean Systems, pp. 4.25–4.30)

questions.question: Which type of sourcing emphasizes building long-term relationships with a few suppliers?
questions.explanation: Single sourcing develops strong partnerships with one supplier to improve collaboration.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 1 – Strategy (Supplier Relationships, pp. 1.55–1.60)

questions.question: Which master scheduling tool links independent demand to material and capacity plans?

questions.question: Which production environment produces standard products continuously without interruption?

questions.question: Which quality tool visually displays steps in a process to identify bottlenecks and inefficiencies?

questions.question: Which planning horizon typically covers 3–18 months and bridges long-range strategy with short-term scheduling?

questions.question: Which demand type comes directly from customer orders and not from forecasts?

questions.question: Which technique measures how well actual production output meets the planned schedule?
questions.explanation: Schedule adherence tracks the percentage of production orders completed as planned.

questions.question: Which strategy involves sourcing components globally to reduce cost or access capabilities?
questions.explanation: Global sourcing leverages worldwide suppliers for cost savings and capability access.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 1 – Strategy (Sourcing Strategies, pp. 1.60–1.65)

questions.question: Which approach schedules production backward from the due date to minimize inventory holding?

questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling (Scheduling Logic, pp. 3.25–3.30)

questions.question: Which inventory valuation method assumes the oldest inventory is sold first?
questions.explanation: FIFO (First In, First Out) assumes the oldest inventory is issued first, common in perishable industries.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Inventory Valuation, pp. 4.30–4.35)

questions.question: Which lean tool reduces machine setup times to enable smaller lot sizes?
questions.explanation: Single-Minute Exchange of Die (SMED) reduces changeover times and supports lean flexibility.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Continuous Improvement (Lean Tools, pp. 4.30–4.35)

questions.question: Which output from material requirements planning specifies what needs to be ordered and when?
questions.explanation: Planned order releases are MRP’s key output, driving purchase and production orders.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – Master Planning (MRP Outputs, pp. 2.40–2.45)

questions.question: Which performance metric measures the average time between placing an order with a supplier and receiving it?
questions.explanation: Lead time measures the elapsed time from order placement to receipt.

questions.question: Which system emphasizes visual control by limiting work-in-process to balance workflow?
questions.explanation: Kanban uses visual signals to limit WIP and balance production.

questions.question: Which inventory performance measure indicates how many times inventory is sold and replaced in a year?
questions.explanation: Inventory turnover measures efficiency in using and replenishing stock.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Metrics, pp. 4.40–4.45)

questions.question: Which document provides authorization to produce a specific quantity of an item?
questions.explanation: A work order authorizes production of a given quantity of a product or component.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling (Production Documents, pp. 3.15–3.20)

questions.question: Which safety stock approach protects against variability in both demand and supply lead time?
questions.explanation: Buffer stock (safety stock) ensures protection against uncertainty in demand and supply.

questions.question: Which capacity planning technique uses bills of resources to validate master schedules?

questions.question: Which process identifies and reduces non-value-added activities in the supply chain?

questions.question: Which costing method assigns overhead costs based on activities that drive cost consumption?

questions.question: Which type of maintenance is scheduled at regular intervals to prevent equipment breakdowns?
questions.explanation: Preventive maintenance is scheduled to avoid unexpected breakdowns and extend equipment life.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling (Maintenance, pp. 3.50–3.55)

questions.question: Which strategy delays final product assembly until customer demand is known?
questions.explanation: Postponement delays final product differentiation to reduce risk and inventory costs.

questions.question: Which scheduling technique calculates the start and finish times for each operation based on due dates and resource availability?
questions.explanation: Finite scheduling accounts for limited resources to set realistic start and finish times for each operation.

questions.question: Which method estimates future demand based on relationships between variables such as price, promotion, or seasonality?

questions.question: Which approach schedules production based on customer orders rather than forecasts?

questions.question: Which planning method evaluates whether key resources like labor and machines can support the master production schedule?

questions.question: Which continuous improvement method encourages small, incremental changes by all employees?

questions.question: Which performance metric measures the speed at which a product moves through a production process?

questions.question: Which inventory control system continuously monitors stock levels and triggers replenishment when a minimum level is reached?

questions.question: Which scheduling rule gives priority to jobs with the highest ratio of time remaining to work remaining?
questions.explanation: The critical ratio rule prioritizes jobs based on the ratio of time until due date to the remaining work.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling (Dispatching Rules, pp. 3.30–3.35)

questions.question: Which production strategy maintains inventory to meet anticipated customer demand?
questions.explanation: Make-to-stock strategy produces goods in advance based on forecasted demand to ensure immediate availability.

questions.question: Which method groups machines and operators to produce families of similar products efficiently?

questions.question: Which quality approach emphasizes monitoring and controlling process variation using statistical methods?
questions.explanation: Six Sigma uses statistical techniques to reduce process variation and defects, aiming for near-perfect quality.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 4 – Continuous Improvement (Six Sigma, pp. 4.20–4.25)

questions.question: Which inventory policy accumulates demand over fixed periods and places one order to cover the total?

questions.question: Which lean technique uses visual signals to trigger replenishment or production activities?

questions.question: Which project management technique identifies the sequence of tasks that directly affects project completion time?

questions.question: Which material requirement planning input defines the components needed to produce finished goods?

questions.question: Which technique in demand management uses expert judgment and market research instead of historical data?

questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 2 – Demand (Forecasting Methods, pp. 2.25–2.30)

questions.question: Which strategy aims to match production closely with actual customer demand to minimize inventory?
questions.explanation: Chase strategy adjusts production to follow demand patterns, minimizing inventory holding costs.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – Master Planning (Capacity Strategies, pp. 2.35–2.40)

questions.question: Which scheduling method calculates start and finish times without considering resource limitations?
questions.explanation: Infinite loading assumes unlimited resources and schedules orders based solely on demand and processing time.

questions.question: Which type of cost is primarily associated with placing and receiving orders from suppliers?

questions.question: Which inventory type represents stock that has been ordered but not yet received from suppliers?
questions.explanation: Pipeline stock is inventory in transit from suppliers to the production site or warehouse.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Inventory Categories, pp. 4.15–4.20)

questions.question: Which performance metric measures the proportion of demand met directly from available inventory?
questions.explanation: Fill rate is the percentage of customer demand satisfied immediately from stock on hand.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Performance Measures, pp. 4.40–4.45)

questions.question: Which production layout is most suitable for custom, one-of-a-kind products?

questions.question: Which concept in Lean focuses on leveling production to reduce inventory and smooth workflow?

questions.question: Which type of lead time measures the time from order release to order completion?
questions.explanation: Manufacturing lead time is the time required to produce an order once it is released into the production process.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling (Lead Times, pp. 3.10–3.15)

questions.question: Which metric measures the efficiency of a production process by comparing actual output to planned output?
questions.explanation: OEE evaluates how effectively a manufacturing operation is utilized compared to its full potential.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 3 – Detailed Scheduling (Performance Metrics, pp. 3.40–3.45)

questions.question: Which inventory replenishment technique triggers orders when stock reaches a predefined level?
questions.explanation: A reorder point system initiates replenishment when inventory falls to a predetermined threshold.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 4 – Inventory (Replenishment Policies, pp. 4.25–4.30)

questions.question: Which forecasting method establishes relationships between demand and external factors such as price or economic conditions?
questions.explanation: Causal forecasting uses cause-and-effect relationships to predict future demand.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 1, Module 2 – Demand (Forecasting Methods, pp. 2.25–2.30)

questions.question: Which production strategy builds products based on forecast and keeps them in stock until sold?
questions.explanation: Make-to-stock produces goods in anticipation of demand, maintaining inventory to meet expected orders.

questions.question: Which concept in project management represents the flexibility in the schedule without delaying the project?

questions.question: Which lot-sizing technique balances ordering and carrying costs by ordering at fixed intervals?
questions.explanation: Period order quantity consolidates demand over a set number of periods to optimize ordering frequency and inventory levels.

questions.question: Which capacity planning approach evaluates key resources against the master schedule to identify potential bottlenecks?
questions.explanation: CRP analyzes detailed work center capacity to ensure the schedule can be met with available resources.

questions.question: Which Lean tool visually controls inventory and production based on consumption?

questions.question: Which type of bill of materials shows the relationship between subassemblies and finished products in a hierarchical format?

questions.question: Which strategy delays product customization until the latest possible point in the supply chain?
questions.explanation: Postponement reduces inventory risk by delaying differentiation or customization until customer demand is known.
questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 2 – Master Planning (Postponement Strategy, pp. 2.55–2.60)

questions.question: Which scheduling technique starts all jobs as soon as resources are available without considering capacity limits?
questions.explanation: Infinite loading schedules jobs without considering resource capacity, potentially creating overloads.

questions.question: Which performance metric measures the proportion of orders shipped complete and on time without errors?

questions.question: Which type of demand is dependent on the demand for another item, typically a component of a finished product?

questions.question: Which continuous improvement method emphasizes small incremental changes rather than large-scale transformations?

questions.question: Which inventory type exists to decouple dependent processes in production and prevent disruptions?

questions.question: Which type of layout arranges workstations according to the sequence of operations for a specific product?

questions.question: Which MRP input defines the quantity of each component required to produce a finished item?

questions.question: Which sourcing strategy reduces supply risk by using multiple suppliers for the same component?

questions.reference: CPIM Part 2, Module 1 – Strategy (Sourcing Approaches, pp. 1.40–1.45)

questions.question: Which cost type is incurred when inventory runs out and production or sales are disrupted?

questions.question: Which planning approach synchronizes supply and demand by adjusting production rates to actual demand?
questions.explanation: Chase strategy matches production with demand, reducing inventory but requiring flexible resources.

questions.question: Which planning method evaluates whether available capacity can support the Master Production Schedule before detailed scheduling?
questions.explanation: Rough-Cut Capacity Planning checks if critical resources are sufficient to meet the MPS before committing to detailed production plans.

questions.question: Which performance metric measures the proportion of planned production actually completed within a period?
questions.explanation: Capacity utilization compares actual production output to the maximum possible output over a given period.

questions.question: Which inventory type is used to maintain smooth production despite variability in process times or supply delays?
